reviewText: OMG - the best Sorkin yet.  Either he is the best craftsman or he has perfect pitch.  Every word is perfectly placed, perfect meaning, and right on target.  Poetry to the television world.  And the acting and stories, like MASH or West Wing, ripe for the cultural season.  Can't wait for season 2.

Brilliant, Briskly Intelligent Writing was the title for this review when this enormously successful series premiered in June 2012. For some reason Amazon did not make this available either on Video On Demand or in a place where reviews could be written. Now the first season is complete - having finished last night with one of the finest shows of the season. And with the soon to be released DVD set of the first year, we can finally discuss it. To start with, the following response was to the first opening show:

A new series launched on HBO with a star-spangled episode `We just decided to'. As conceived and written by Aaron Sorkin it is a timely, incredibly intelligently written show populated with some of our best seasoned actors as well as some very fine actors on the way up. This is the kind of television that reminds us that at one time the news programs informed us about current events and ran a continuing commentary on the development of events in this country and around the world in a manner that kept us alerted of why we as a nation needed to remain alert to both good and bad events, to celebrate when indicated and to fight back when injustices were occurring. This direction is indicated in the background imagery for the titles - running glimpses of the likes of Walter Cronkite, Edward R Murrow, Huntley/Brinkley etc who were responsible news anchors instead of the flippant celebrities more concerned with ratings of their show than the news we see today.

The first episode opens with popular news anchor Will McAvoy (Jeff Daniels who proves his acting chops here) being interviewed on a college campus and responds to a student question `Why is America the greatest country' by answering `We're not. We used to be' and then runs us past our history of reportage on television that proves that the country has fallen in world view because we no longer care about our initial basic rights and freedoms and concern for humanity. It is a powerful start with some of the most gut-wrenching insightful history of this country that has been written for television

From there, McAvoy returns to his station to find a support team missing and a replacement named. But enter an old flame, the war correspondent fatigued Mackenzie MacHale (Emily Mortimer, never more brilliant) who has been assigned Will's new Executive Producer, and in the midst of many changes the new arrangement (not a popular one for Will) evolves into a return to actual news reporting of the significant type - all over the 2010 BP oil explosion and spill that threatened the Gulf of Mexico. It is raw, real, factual, and immediate news delivered with veracity and commitment.

From this initial episode the series takes on the most significant events that have affected this country in the last 2 years - the major Wall Street disaster, the activity of the Tea Party sector of the Republican Party, the political party with which Will is aligned but in the final episode, after recuperating for a severe bout of depression, he returns to his place at the news desk in the final episode `In Name Only' and ends the season with a diatribe about the current status of his party berating them as a party for their ideological purity, compromise as weakness, a fundamentalist belief in scriptural literalism, denying science, unmoved by facts, undeterred by new information, hostile fear of progress , a demonization of education, a need to control women's bodies, severe xenophobia, tribal mentality, intolerance of dissent, and pathological hatred of the US government. 'They can call themselves the Tea Party, they can call themselves conservatives, and they can even call themselves Republicans, though Republicans probably shouldn't. But we should call them what they are, the American Taliban.'

Greg Mottola and others direct with keen precision, allowing moments of comic relief to be present if subtle and keeps the momentum of the show propelling smoothly. The cast of superb actors includes John Gallagher, Jr. (brilliant), Dev Patel, Allison Pill, Sam Waterston (never better), Thomas Sadoski, Chris Chalk, Trieu Tran, Charlie Weirauch, Margaret Judson, Olivia Munn, Adina Porter, Hope Lange, Jane Fonda - and more. A more talented and committed cast would be hard to imagine. THIS is the kind of television series we so very sorely need right now. It is refreshingly free of the usual clatter and gimmicks that clutter the airways, and it is full of information and food for thought delivered in an entertaining manner. It is simply and unequivocally brilliant! Grady Harp, August 12

First - I REALLY, REALLY, REALLY wanted to like this series. It is cerebral, it has great actors, it makes you think a little while entertaining you; it isn't written for the lowest common denominator.

However, despite all of the positives, the writers still failed to pry themselves away from their deep seated liberal ideology.  They portray the media as noble but the writers fail to be honest in the end. The premise of the series is that the media has some sort of epiphany and suddenly obtains character and integrity. On top of that, the writers try to appear balanced but just cannot resist making liberals appear to be intelligent while taking cheap shots at conservatives. It's subtle but pervasive, like when they portray the main character's Republican past as a negative that needs to be hidden or spun.

Then, when the story wanders away from ideology it falls headlong into romantic tension. Half of the story is attempting to tell you that the press really is noble and the other half is a full blown soap opera. If they added anymore sexual tension or romantic interest, you would think it was a reality TV show set in a high school.

Newsroom had GREAT potential and once again the liberal mindset of the entertainment industry just couldn't trust the viewer to sort out the information on their own. The viewer is constantly being told that being liberal automatically makes one smart and adhering to conservative values makes one evil and dull.

Jeff Daniels does a great job. The supporting characters have depth although they look as if they drawn out of a politically correct  lotto machine, They have females, African Americans, Asians, Indians, Blue collar white guys, you name it. The casting oozes diversity to the point that it is almost comical. I was almost waiting for a lesbian single mother in a wheelchair to appear in some episode so the producers could check that box as well.

The use of real events as the backdrop for the news stories was brilliant. The writers don't need to explain what the events are and can focus on the story line. Unfortunately, they  couldn't pass up the opportunity to also tell the viewer that conservatives were either to blame for the events or couldn't possible be intelligent in each and every one of those stories.

The show dives into several news issues but only covers them from one very limited perspective and out of context, yet they come across as if they got the real story. In essence, the show criticizes major news outlets for nor reporting news fairly, yet Newsroom itself is guilty of pretending to report news fairly but clearly doesn't. Only Aaron Sorkin himself could write a sufficiently eloquent review of this series; one that would definitively capture the magnitude of greatness of the writing, the acting, the editing and the choice of subject matter for each episode.  I have no expertise in writing quality or specific knowledge of broadcasting, but by the 4th episode found myself genuinely disappointed at the realization that this series ended after only 3 seasons.  It is incredibly good--poignantly topical, exceptionally thought provoking, and undeniably effective at reminding us of the potential beauty and insight that can be conveyed with such an exceptional and deliberate choice of language.  I think anyone could enjoy and appreciate this show, regardless of personal politics, or one's opinion of the role and result that the media has played in all of our lives.  The goal of this script seems not to lecture the audience with Sorkin's opinions about government, politics and the media--instead it appears to strive to get us to actively consider and reflect on the ways in which we all are affected by these dominant forces in our lives every day.  We are all affected by these things and likely have considered many of these themes in our own lives at one point or another, but generally move on all too quickly to other thoughts, because the details of our daily lives take a front seat to these seemingly philosophical reflections. And rather than preaching his own opinions to us, I thought Sorkin seemed to be imploring us to think critically about the things that affect us, even when it's easier to move on to the practical necessities of issues that are more tangible in our daily lives.  And I found the actors to all be impressively believable in their roles, as well as the editing/directing choices to be impressive.  It was also very interesting to consider each of these major events from the past decade from such a different perspective of a newsroom as the knowledge of such events was breaking in real time, as opposed to the perspective that we the audience experienced as we learned about them from the various media outlets.  There are too many reasons to watch this series; more than a typical review could possibly address.  And too many perfectly timed metaphors and references to prioritize them.  Although I think my favorite (admittedly for purely personal reasons) was the episode in which the staff all lined up to donate personal checks to Will, as a contribution to the money he had personally paid in order to free a captured free-lance journalist abroad.... straight out of the movie "Rudy", which is a tough choice to effectively reference/copy and not fall short of success at meeting such a massive emotional response  But this episode was brilliantly successful.  It made me appreciate Sorkin that much more for thinking of it as a way to communicate his message with his script.  I cannot say enough wonderful things about this show--just do yourself a favor and watch it.

Aaron Sorkin's latest look at social issues through the lens of a TV show (Sports Night and Studio 60) has many of his usual touches: rapid-fire insightful dialogue, fast pace and great acting. Season 1 seeks to inspire with Will's quest to bring civility into the "public square" of cable media. The backward looking format that includes news of the recent past allows the viewer to put those events in context with the storytelling.
Although some reviewers (possibly rightly) knock the show for female characters that are cartoonishly inept with some aspects of their lives, those characters are also brilliant, strong and the soul of The Newsroom and the fictional show they produce.
Season 1 makes a great case for being well informed and getting information from reliable sources, something relevant to recent events in the US. Engagement, Civics, just giving a damn about what's going on in our country is important. Sorkin makes the case that good citizenship requires that we be well informed and that we must be wise consumers of the information available to us.

AS one might expect from writer Aaron Sorkin (who also did much of the best writing for THE WEST WING), this is one of the most intelligent, insightful, and honest shows I have ever seen.  It depicts the moral and economic challenges and conflicts television news organizations face every day in addition to verifying sources of information.  It challenges the motivations of all news organizations in the same way that the best churches challenge their congregations: to live a courageous and moral life, to stand up to bullies and the easy temptations of profit and cronyism.  While doing this THE NEWSROOM also reveals the humanity of its characters, the personal and professional conflicts, ambitions, and jealousies, the internal conflicts (popularity or truth?), how honor might be expressed, what unconscious biases we all contain and how they impact our personal and professional worlds.
This is a 2-season morality play on several levels.  It inspires one to think and feel as well as to be entertained. I applaud the clever writing, the excellent acting, the engagement of the entire team and the engagement it created in me. I felt like a member of this team. I endorse this show enthusiastically.

This season starts with the premise of a very smart news anchor, who, for personal reasons, decides to get a conscience, and drags his production team with him.
Every episode is frame within a specific, real life event, from a marathon bombing to the capture of Bin Laden.  Each one of them is filled with the drama one can hope from events that changed United States history.  They end also, with Will McAvoy editorial as the closing statement from the episode.
Even with the internal drama derived from the characters personal dilemmas, you cannot help but be touched by their reaction about the shattering events they are reporting about.
In one of the episodes, part of the production team is stuck in a plane while the events about the killing of Bin Laden are unfolding.  One of the producers is complaining about not being able to get down from the plane to do his job, until he sees the captain, and realizes he is traveling in a United Airlines plane.  His attitude changes immediately, from a really annoying person, to a moved individual who cannot help himself, and with the outmost respect, simply tells the captain that Bin Laden has been captured.
This season, all the historical facts are treated in a serious and respectful way.  Although the following two seasons would be excellent as well, these history based episodes are only used on the first one and initiate what would be, although very short, one of my favorite series.
Do yourself a favor, and watch this, you won't regret it.

First let me say this up-front: The Newsroom is an idealization of what the news ought to be in the Internet age.  In this series, Sorkin essentially rewrites how the major stories of the day (BP oil spill, the financial crisis, the assassination of Osama bin Laden) ought to have  been reported.  And (even though he does give Will a conservative thought or two) Sorkin writes about these and other issues from a liberal perspective.  So thats one problem.  The other is that he never really comes to grips with how a news organization is supposed to make money in the Internet age where everyone has a voice.  (As you can readily see because you are reading these pearls of wisdom on an Internet site.)  And when Newsroom does try to tackle the whole money question it fails rather miserably.  Lucas (the billionaire who buys the Atlantis Cable News and tries to make it into something a kind of over-the-top Fox is treated with the utmost disdain.  But then the old billionaire-owner (Leona) didn't get much sympathy when she merely tried to use her news network for political influence.  So, money (or rather the need to make a profit) is not an issue that is treated with any seriousness here.  This is an idealistic series.

Having said that (and there are a lot of criticisms that can be and have been leveled at Newsroom fairly and perhaps not as fairly), it is an absorbing show.  I think there are two reasons for that.  First of all, while it definitely has a liberal bias, it is not a blindly liberal bias.  There are several characters (Will is a good example) of conservative points of view.  The show side-steps the whole GOP infighting by having Will bemoan how his party is being hijacked by the Tea Party (and who thereby lower news standards) but he does express what are legitimate conservative concerns about the GOP and the world at large.  But more than that, the characters on the show are all to a greater or lesser degree deeply flawed and deeply committed.  And as a result, they both exemplify the forces that are tearing us apart right now and, at the same time, because they are forced to work together (and hence talk to one another) in order to produce this one show, they somehow find exactly the right response to any story as it happens.

Their responses to the oil spill and Osama bin Laden perhaps encapsulates this better than anything.  That, and the really good acting made me sit and root for the characters.  And it kept me watching.

And yes I know all the criticisms.  Its liberal; in real life they would have gone off air in a heartbeat because really who watches actual news anymore? Etc. But a part of me rejects that.  Because wouldnt it be nice if I could turn on the news and get the Newsroom?

The true virtue of this short lived series from HBO beyond its stellar performances, the quality and intelligence of the writing and the sophistication of its humor is that it manages to accomplish in reality the very thing that it addresses fictitiously. Namely; it gives us an accurate and unbiased (as much as that it possible for entertainment) account of real events that we never got from the national news media.  It doesn't address everything but it puts so much of what's happened in the first years of the new millennium not only in the spotlight but under the magnifying lens that the Fourth Estate once held as an indispensible tool.  A tool that was shattered when news media became just another facet of the entertainment industry and manipulated by corporations for their own selfish ends. Great cast, well written (actually very well composed dialogue) and an above average ensemble chemistry all make for an engaging viewing experience while exploring the 'what if' of the existence another cable news organization that fell ideologically right of CNN and to the left of Fox.

The riveting re-reporting of actual news stories from the past several years heightens the drama.

If your ideological bent is to the right of Fox, be forewarned that all of your fears about how the reporters have an ideological axe to grind will appear to be proven with this show.  If your passions lean to the left, you'll feel very vindicated in the scenes where groups on the right side of the aisle are pilloried with regularity.

But remember it IS a drama. While using current real world events as a plot device, it has many redeeming aspects in accurately representing how news is reported in the real life career.

As a full blown tech geek myself, their inclusion of the production studio as a cast member is both interesting and fascinating. Their use of smartphones, social media websites and the ubiquitous apps -much as we all now do nowadays - is another strong touch for their take on realism.

If you have ever become a little sleepy while watching any of the current leading network news programs, perhaps there may be a good  reason behind your lack of alert, engaged, attention. This series is a hypothetical counter to the way news is too often delivered today, as entertainment driven by ratings. It is not a perfect portrayal of insuring an informed electorate, but a very good attempt in the right direction. I have watched both the first and second season twice now, and continue to be appreciative of this "what if" drama about news that transcends the often shallow and banal broadcasts touting themselves as news these days. If you admired the commitment of Edward R. Morrow and Walter Cronkite to integrity, honesty, and the pursuit of an honorable calling, that of keeping the public informed regarding news that really matters, try this HBO series out for at least the first episode. It may just renew your faith in depth reporting, and a hope that more of it will begin to flourish in these troubled times that requiri everyone to employ their best informed critical thinking.

This is the most intelligent show I've ever seen produced in this country. The writing and directing are top-flight, with plot lines so intricately interwoven that we, the audience, are genuinely drawn deeply into what truly feels like a real-life drama, in that so much of what we know and learn of the characters and their complex relationships is based upon seeming events that took place out of our gaze-just as in real life. The way they accomplish this is purely brilliant!!! An additional aspect of the writing that puts it so far ahead of anything else coming out of my old stomping grounds is that the dialogue and the characters' values are such that each actor has the leeway to be great-none are  too constrained by a need to adhere to any audience pre-conceptions. From one writer to another: Aaaron Sorkin is AWESOME! But my last substantive comment requires that I segue to an appreciation of the acting & direction. I've always been a fan of Jeff Daniels but, as Will McIlvoy, he spreads his wings as I've never seen before. F'ing fantastic! And I've appreciated Sam Waterston immensely, particularly in the original "Law & Order," but I find his performances here so much more  delightful because they reveal the emotional &intellectual complexities of his character far more effectively than was done in L&O. But the show would not be so terrific were it not equally due to the outstanding work of all the other actors. ALL of them. I don't know which of the three lead women I adore more as each is so rich and real that their physical appeal does not get in the way. Even Olivia Munn's off-the-charts sexuality doesn't keep the viewer from feeling her very real vulnerabilities and haven't we all worked with someone like Maggie who is as charming & insanely cute as she is insecure? And Mac is just....WOW!!!! But not too over -the-top as I knew women at my old law firm  who had her intense idealism combined with an amazing, but quite believable, ability to juggle a thousand & one stressors and pull it off [nearly] every time. Furthermore, while 99% of what is on TV is totally unappealing to me, watching  "The Newsroom" not only does not require that I take a very hot shower afterwards to cleanse myself, but it forces me to confront many vital issues in politics, media and current society with which I am already grappling every day, so this show is so very much right in my wheelhouse!! Finally, as with great literature and top-flight motion pictures, I enjoy each episode more with every successive viewing, with seemingly always more to notice as I slap myself on the forehead and scold myself for having missed it before while my eyes well-up with emotions as I feel connected to what is going on before me as I never before experienced watching but a mere TV show. Until I saw "The Newsroom." P.S. Sucks that it was on for but 3 years! REALLY sucks!

We hear what the often so called newscasters "think" and which celebrity did what outrageous thing today.  What we need is factual news reported with an eye toward informing the public about events that effect our daily lives and long-term world view. Although plainly presented from a liberal perspective, Sorkin used events, clips, and quotes that easily showed the bias and hypocrisy of various political factions, especially the Tea Party and certain screaming heads claiming to be sources of truth and fact.

Overall, this first season was a blend of drama, humor, and political commentary about the state of the world with a little satire and sarcasm thrown in for good measure.  He employed an excellent cast to convey complex stories, though he sometimes has trouble writing consistent female characters and reigning them in over time.  It was refreshing to see favorite actors who have entertained us for many decades sharing the stage and working naturally with younger, less well known actors.

The series used topical stories that had already played out, so we weren't surprised by the episode plots.  Instead we were engaged in the way the stories developed, how they were presented, and the way people reacted to them.  I highly recommend the first season of "The Newsroom" to everyone.

As a 35-plus year journalist I love the way they approach news and information and the public's right know on this show.  It's Sorkin so of course it is intelligent, witty and it never talks down to its viewers.  It is an idealized version of what we want and really should get from broadcast journalism every day and night. I love the characters and the cast for the most part.  Daniels, Sam Waterston and Jane Fonda are brilliant. Olivia Munn (Sloan) and Thomas Sadoski (Don) are my favorites and are great at balancing humor and drama and have wonderful screen chemistry. Most of the supporting cast is fine  Neal is the most interesting of that crew.  However, I do find Mackenzie very irritating, mostly on the personal side of her life, but just as a character.  She tries too hard to be cute all of the time, and uses that even on her professional level. It is hard for me to believe she was embedded with real troops seeing real action.  Jim, her protege, is self-righteous at times.  I never was able to believe Maggie in her role. She never came across as a professional. She seemed more an earnest "I'll try real hard" college student journalist.  But yes when I need a reminder of what we should get and what I hope to see every morning/night on my TV I turn to this show.
